title: Google Principal Engineer: Claude Code recreated in 1 hour what took team a year
description: Jaana Dogan, Principal Engineer at Google, shared that Claude Code successfully generated in one hour what her team had built over the past year for distributed agent orchestrators. Used a three-paragraph description with no proprietary details. Simon Willison commented on how AI assistance is bringing people back to coding who had stopped due to management roles or parenting - allowing useful work in 30 minutes rather than requiring 2-4 hour ramp-up. Management experience transfers well to 'managing' coding agents: communicate clearly, set achievable goals, provide relevant context.
author: Simon Willison (quoting Jaana Dogan)

title: Hacker News top blogs of 2025: Simon Willison ranks #1 for third year
description: Simon Willison's blog ranked #1 on Hacker News for 2023, 2024, and 2025, but ranks #3 all-time behind Paul Graham and Brian Krebs. Uses HN Popularity Contest site with open CORS headers enabling exploration with Datasette Lite. The data powers rankings through scoring based on how well blogs perform on HN. Simon demonstrated using Claude Opus 4.5 to write a convoluted window function query to show domain rankings by year.
author: Simon Willison

title: In 2026, AI will move from hype to pragmatism
description: TechCrunch analysis predicting 2026 as transition year from brute-force scaling to practical AI deployment. Key trends: (1) Move away from scaling laws toward new architectures, (2) Smaller Language Models (SLMs) fine-tuned for domain-specific enterprise use, (3) World models that learn 3D spatial reasoning and physical interactions, (4) Model Context Protocol (MCP) becoming 'USB-C for AI' to connect agents to real tools, (5) Shift from automation to augmentation - '2026 will be the year of the humans', (6) Physical AI with wearables, smart glasses, and robotics becoming mainstream.
author: Rebecca Bellan

title: A new worst coder has entered the chat: vibe coding without code knowledge
description: First-person account from non-developer using Bolt's vibe coding tool to create a Reddit bathroom review app. Reveals critical gaps in AI coding promise: (1) Tool successfully created working app in ~10 minutes, (2) But code was messy, disorganized, nearly impossible to understand, (3) No security features - data completely exposed to anyone using inspect function, (4) No unit tests, 'productivity tax' where developers must clean up AI-generated code, (5) Highlights danger of 'vibe coding' for production apps without developer oversight. 66% of developers report experiencing this productivity tax.
author: Stack Overflow Blog

title: 2025: The year in LLMs - comprehensive annual review
description: Simon Willison's third annual LLM review covering 27 major developments: (1) Year of reasoning models and RLVR (Reinforcement Learning from Verifiable Rewards), (2) Rise of coding agents (Claude Code), (3) $200/month AI subscriptions, (4) Chinese open-weight models dominating, (5) Long tasks capability doubling every 7 months, (6) Nano Banana for prompt-driven image editing, (7) Models winning gold in academic competitions, (8) Llama 'losing its way', (9) OpenAI losing lead to Gemini, (10) Vibe coding phenomenon, (11) MCP (Model Context Protocol) emergence, (12) AI-enabled browsers, (13) 'Lethal trifecta' security concept, (14) Programming on phones, (15) Conformance suites for AI testing, (16) Local vs cloud model trade-offs, (17) 'Slop' as word of the year, (18) Data center unpopularity.
author: Simon Willison

title: An experiment in vibe coding: Building a travel app without editing code
description: Nolan Lawson built a travel itinerary app for his wife using only 'vibe coding' - directing AI tools without editing code himself. Results: (1) Built with $20 Claude pro plan and ~5 hours work over holidays, (2) Started with Bolt.new but switched to Claude Code when Bolt fell off after first iteration, (3) Successfully replaced Supabase with PocketBase on Claude's recommendation, (4) App works as PWA with Railway hosting for $1/month, (5) The ugly parts: LLMs still suck at accessibility (lots of divs with onClick), performance issues due to React re-rendering requiring memoization fixes, (6) Vibe coding tools are 'decidedly NOT ready for non-programmers yet' - his wife got frustrated quickly without debugging experience, (7) Concluded vibe coding works for hobby/throwaway projects but 'for my regular dayjob, I have no intention to do things fully vibe-coded - that's just too risky and irresponsible'.
author: Nolan Lawson
